title: 108_s759
content: The Act is titled the "Residential, Farm, Ranch, and Small Business Wind Energy Systems Act of 2003" or the "Small Wind Energy Systems Act of 2003." It introduces a credit for residential small wind energy systems under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act allows a 30% tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures made by individuals. The credit is limited to $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity and requires safety certifications. Any excess credit can be carried forward to future years. The Act allows a 30% tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures made by individuals, limited to $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity and requiring safety certifications. Any excess credit can be carried forward to future years if it exceeds the limitation imposed by section 26(a). The term 'qualified wind energy property expenditure' refers to expenses for wind energy property installed in a US dwelling used as a residence, including installation fees. 'Qualified wind energy property' is a wind turbine with a 5-year warranty, starting with the taxpayer. The term 'qualifying wind turbine' refers to a wind turbine with a rated capacity of 75 kilowatts or less, meeting performance standards set by industry associations within one year of purchase. The turbine must have a 5-year warranty covering defects in design, material, workmanship, and installation. Expenditures for labor costs related to the onsite preparation, assembly, or installation of qualified wind energy property and for interconnecting piping or wiring are eligible for consideration. Additionally, expenses allocated to energy storage mediums like swimming pools or hot tubs are also included. Expenditures for labor costs related to onsite preparation, assembly, or installation of qualified wind energy property and interconnecting piping or wiring are eligible. Expenses for energy storage mediums like swimming pools or hot tubs are not considered for the credit. Special rules apply for joint occupancy of a dwelling unit. In cases of joint occupancy of a dwelling unit, the credit allowable for expenditures made by individuals living together is determined by treating them as one taxpayer. Each individual is eligible for a credit for their share of the expenditures in the taxable year. Taxpayers can claim a credit for expenditures made in a calendar year. Tenant-stockholders in cooperative housing corporations are also eligible for this credit. Individuals who are tenant-stockholders in cooperative housing corporations or members of condominium management associations can claim a credit for their proportionate share of expenditures made by the corporation or association. Individuals who are members of a condominium management association are treated as having made their proportionate share of any expenditures. The term 'condominium management association' refers to an organization meeting specific requirements for a condominium project used primarily as residences. If less than 80 percent of a qualified wind energy property is used for nonbusiness purposes, individuals can claim a credit for energy generation. The text discusses the allocation of expenditures for qualified wind energy property used for nonbusiness purposes and energy generation. It specifies that only the portion of expenditures properly allocable to these purposes can be considered. The expenditure is deemed made when the property is installed and begins to be used. Expenditures for qualified wind energy property are treated as made when the property is installed and begins to generate energy. The amount of the expenditure is the cost incurred. Expenditures for qualified wind energy property are treated as made when the original use of the structure begins. The amount of the expenditure is the cost incurred. Expenditures made from subsidized energy financing are not taken into account. Basis adjustments are made if a credit is allowed for any expenditure on qualified wind energy property. The section allows for a credit on qualified wind energy property expenditures, with basis adjustments made accordingly. The credit is not applicable to property installed after December 31, 2008. The credit is limited based on the amount of tax liability. The Code of 1986 is amended to limit the tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures based on the amount of tax liability. Section 25C is added to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code, including sections 1016 and 1400C, for tax credits related to wind energy property expenditures. The amendments made by section 25C apply to residential wind energy property expenditures after December 31, 2002, for taxable years ending after that date. The amendments made by subsection (b) apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2003. Additionally, a credit is provided for business installation of small wind energy property. The amendment defines qualified wind energy property as a qualifying wind turbine installed before January 1, 2009. The amendment defines qualified wind energy property as a qualifying wind turbine installed on a farm, ranch, or eligible small business in the US, owned and used by the taxpayer, with the original use starting with the taxpayer and a 5-year warranty. The amendment specifies that qualified wind energy property must be a qualifying wind turbine owned and used by the taxpayer, with the original use starting with the taxpayer and a 5-year warranty.
